thread.title: Paul A. Smith - Snowy owls fly south for the fall
thread.title_full: Paul A. Smith - Snowy owls fly south for the fall

author: Paul A. Smith
title: Paul A. Smith - Snowy owls fly south for the fall
text:
Snowy owls, the big, white birds that nest in the Arctic and sometimes fly south in the fall and winter, have begun showing up in Wisconsin over the last week, captivating wildlife watchers and raising questions among scientists.
About 30 snowy sightings were reported through Wednesday in Wisconsin, according to Ryan Brady, a wildlife biologist with the Department of Natural Resources who oversees the Wisconsin eBird website.
The reports are earlier in the season and higher in number than any year on record.
"It's unprecedented," said Tom Erdman, curator of the Richter Museum of Natural History at UW-Green Bay who began conducting snowy owl research in Wisconsin in the late 1950s. "It's causing us to ask 'Why?"
The first snowy of the season was sighted Oct. 15 near Ashland in Bayfield County on Lake Superior. The next day one was seen in Crawford County in southwestern Wisconsin. On Tuesday lone snowies were reported in Kohler and Milwaukee.
And on Cat Island in Green Bay earlier this week, six snowies were seen at once, Erdman said.
Last year, the first snowy was reported in Wisconsin on Nov. 1. In 2013, the initial observation was Nov. 15.
In recent decades, the first snowies have typically appeared in Wisconsin in mid-November, Brady said.
"This year is completely taking people by surprise," Brady said.
So far this fall, snowy owls have been reported in the western Great Lakes region, but none in the eastern U.S.
Snowy owls are about two feet tall and weigh from 2 to 6 pounds, the largest owl by weight in North America.
Sporting white plumage — with dark bars in female and younger birds — and luminous yellow eyes, the species has captured the fancy of humans long before Harry Potter books and movies came on the scene.
Scientists have closely documented the species' movements into the U.S. since the 1800s. The data have shown relatively large southerly flights called "irruptions" about once every four or five years, Erdman said.
The movements typically take place during years of high availability of lemmings — the primary prey of snowy owls in the Arctic — and high productivity of snowy owls.
Once fledged, the young owls disperse to areas with less competition for food.
But through history such years of high owl production occurred only periodically. The irruptions are now becoming "commonplace," Erdman said.
Wisconsin experienced snowy owl irruptions in 2011-'12, 2013-'14 and 2014-'15.
Modern data collection techniques are helping scientists determine the number of snowies that venture into Wisconsin each year.
Brady said 290 "unique" snowies were recorded in the state in 2013-'14. Last winter, also a significant flight, saw 280 snowies in Wisconsin.
Although it's still early, Erdman said it looks like this will be the third irruption in a row and fourth in five years.
"There have been years when we had 30 birds in the whole state over an entire winter," Erdman said. "We've already had 30 birds this year in October. And we've never had three in a row. Something is going on."
Erdman's hunch is related to climate change. He said a warmer Arctic could be increasing the habitat and abundance of lemmings, allowing snowy owls to produce more offspring more often.
In years of low prey availability, snowy owls won't nest at all. If it's a really good year, a pair of adults may fledge 10 young owls.
Since very few researchers work in the expansive Arctic, it's difficult to get an accurate picture of lemming numbers and owl production, said David Brinker, a scientist with Project SNOWstorm and the Maryland Department of Natural Resources.
"We are learning more each year, but there are still more questions than answers," Brinker said. "But when we get an irruption, the opportunity to study birds is right in front of us."
Project SNOWstorm placed transmitters on 34 snowy owls in the U.S. in the last two years. The devices allow scientists to track the birds and learn which habitats are preferred by snowy owls on their southern ranges as well as where they return in summer.
Brinker said the Project SNOWstorm team met a week ago in Cape May, New Jersey to discuss plans for the season. They have loads of data to process and reports to write, he said.
"These owls create an extraordinary level of excitement among the public and scientists," Brinker said. "The early reports from Wisconsin are causing us to re-evaluate our plans."
Studies have shown snowy owls prey mostly on voles and other rodents in Wisconsin, as well as some birds.
Among the first orders of business for scientists in Wisconsin is to determine the ages of snowies being observed. Brady said young-of-the-year or subadult birds comprise most owls in an irruption.
Also, Brady said it was important to for the public to give plenty of space to any snowy owl they see. The birds are likely exhausted and hungry after a long migration, he said, and it's important to not stress the owls.
It's often difficult to tell the difference between an owl that is healthy and resting from one that is sick or injured. If in doubt, stay a good distance away and call a local DNR wildlife biologist for advice, Brady said.
Onlookers in Kohler did just that earlier this week after they saw a snowy sitting on the hood of a vehicle in a Kohler Corp. parking lot. When a DNR employee arrived, the owl flew away.
It was one of the first of what promises to be many snowy owls seen in the Badger State this year.
The reasons behind the frequent irruptions may not be known for years. And they could well have ominous implications for wildlife in the Arctic and beyond.
But for the present, when it comes to the appearance of white objects in Wisconsin in fall, there's none more welcome than a snowy owl.
